author: __deandre
body:
>What happens if you run it starting at December 2017

Something similar to starting in January 2018 (plus one insane month), which is listed in the post. Rerunning will take a few hours, but some quick tests show:

* Buy&Hold goes from -70% (Jan 2018) to -40% (Dec 2017). Had to remove BNB because it has hundreds of % gains in Dec and completely skews the results
* MA Cross (EMA) goes from +40% to +95%
* MA Cross (SuperSmoother) goes from +110% to +195%

>Are you using the 25 top coins as of today, or the ones that were the top at the time the experiment started?

TOP at start of 2018. I have the coins listed under "Coins and date ranges used". Most current TOP coins don't have that much data history.

author: ixamnis
body:
This. I'd put roughly the same amount into both.

That said, you might want to consider putting it into an ETF called **XLK**.  **XLK** is the SPDR Technology Select ETF.  This ETF is 23.9% Apple and 20.3% Microsoft. This means, you'd be investing nearly equal amounts into both of those stocks and that would be almost half of this ETF. This would also help you diversify your holdings a little bit.

The next holdings in the ETFs portfolio include:

**V**  (VISA) - 4.29%

**NVDA** (NVIDIA) - 4.25%

**MA** (Mastercard) - 3.80%

**ADBE** (Adobe) - 2.99%

**PYPL** (Paypal) - 2.94%

**CRM** (Salesforce) - 2.80%

**INTC** (Intel) - 2.80%

**CSCO** (Cisco Systems) - 2.12%

&#x200B;

Hope this helps.

author: SirGasleak
body: I don't think any trading software can accommodate that.  You basically have to create your own stop order and keep adjusting it based on the trend of the MA.  That said, it's also not a great idea to create stop-loss orders around moving averages because that's what a lot of retail investors do, so institutional investors know they can buy at that level.  That's why it isn't uncommon to see false breakdowns, where a stock dips below the MA and then reverses and moves back above.

author: MrOz1100
body: I heavily invested in DFS at the bottom because I knew they had upped their loss provisions months before and their earnings numbers weren’t real. That has about tripled since and I’m confident it’ll go up higher as they unveil new numbers that will look like large earnings but will actually be the aftermath of over hedging. I’m holding that medium term. There is of course msft, Apple, mastercard some of the usual high ROE suspects. Then I have my side projects like KBAL an office furniture company (I know talk about bad growth ops) but that I believe is being unfairly penalized in the market and I believe they’re a good value play right now. Also they have a good debt situation and plenty of cash relative to their size. In addition I invested in NMIH at the bottom which deals with private mortgage insurances. That play has doubled and I’m confident that it will continue to go up. There’s a bunch of others these are just what I came up with top of head. I’m not saying CVS has no place in a portfolio of course I just think there are better options

author: snyder810
body:
If I legit had to do this then GOOGL, LMT, MSFT, MA, & JNJ. No sell rule would have me risk averse and wanting to make picks that will pace with, or close to, the market in a worst case scenario with low risk of a major flame out.

The more fun list:
LRCX - it’s more and more of a tech driven world, they’re an innovative leader helping enable it to happen.

SQ - if they can become what they’re trying to then they’ll be the fin-tech leader in 10 years.

CRM - not only a current leader in the SaaS space, but they’ve consistently made solid acquisitions and great investments. This just seems to be one of the best run companies right now, and I’d wager on them staying one of the growth leaders over the next 5-10 years.

AMZN - History says their growth will slow, but do you really want to bet against their world takeover given only the knowledge we currently have? 

VEEV - I should have bought in years ago, drug trials aren’t stopping and there isn’t currently any meaningful competition for their market. Not only do they have the first mover advantage, I can see it being very sticky even with competitors given the nature of the customer base.

author: gammaradiation2
body:
Well yes, the NE is almost as fucked as the west coast. However and overall, we wont see a nation wide real estate bust as long as the middle class and up are working (they are, the middle class does not subsist on the service sector) and interest rates stay low (they will, any inflation caused by the recovery will correct the historically low inflation we have seen over the past 5 yrs). 

NY, NJ, MA, CA, WA, etc are about to suffer, but the south east, midwest, Nevada, etc.. are going to continue to boom. Its just moving money, not losing money.

author: technocrat_landlord
body: I would go with MA over V. They have lower profit margins and lower market share. If they can improve on these areas it will allow them to significantly increase valuation. Plus, they are investing heavily in digital payments (I work on one of the digital payments teams, so I miiight be biased lol)

author: hak8or
body:
And far more during the colder months. While many restaurants died because they couldn't weather the initial shutdown attempts against covid, there are many which are barely surviving because they get to have out door dining.

As the weather cools, out door dining will be far less feasible, causing even more to die at this point.

It's such a shame, if everyone wore masks and socially distanced from the beginning, and stayed home if they had covid, then this wouldn't have happened. We would have been in a much better position now.

author: nitebeest
body:
Usually leading up to a big event, IV is usually >100. Depending on the company and what is going on it can easily be 150-200+.

Edit: for example, TSLA, with not a lot going on right now is still >70. NKLA is >200 with everything going on right now. Some of the bigger ERs last quarter had IV jumping up in that 150+ range easy.

author: scopolamine
body:
Gary Kaltbaum is on fire:

>Look, my biggest worry with JPow is that he thinks that he is a God. The thing is that somebody tickle with what inflation or deflation is gonna do down the road or keep rates 0% for the next 3 years, you gotta give me a break with that. And I gotta tell you, nobody is asking JPow one question that I would be asking if I was in FOMC press conference. So Mr. Powell, if the markets drop 10%, would you just print another $10TN, what number would you go to, what number is high enough for you? And nobody is asking that question. And that is the big worry. He can never ever rollback what he is doing now. If he today just said I am gonna stop printing money, Dow would be down a thousand points and that is what I mean by markets being addicted. I just wish he would back away from financial markets, because that is not going to be about real economy and employers and employee. Not him tinkering with printing money and buying APPL bonds.

He is not wrong though.

author: bonghits96
body:
> Even if TD leaves me holding bags after ticker switch, the SP would have to drop an additional 30% for selling the warrants to make sense. Am I wrong?

You're not wrong. With the warrants at 23.50 you breakeven if the common price is at $35 once you can exercise the warrants. Everything above that is gravy. With SHLL at 47.80, if you actually like the company and intend to hold it for a while, the warrants are the way to go.

That doesn't mean anything is guaranteed--the common can drop below that $35 figure--but your odds are better in the warrants than the common right now.

author: jfelski
body:
It did have a reverse split in 2005 and 2007 but both were only a 2-1 split. This does not appear to be what screwed you. The company filed bankruptcy and as part of the restructuring dropped their outstanding shares into warrants, at a conversion of 2.5%. The warrants are good for three years for the new ticker, DEN. Long story short, the company fucked you big time. Turned your shares into shit, restructured, launched new shares at around $17 a share and now have a shit ton of cash and you have a warrant for the new stock. Good luck. 

Plus side, the warrants are up 96% premarket today, told you to buy the dip....lol

author: sirvapedalot
body:
Good luck getting around their 45 patents including foundational ones like the patent of “High Definition Lidar Systems”. There is a reason they have already been able to enforce the patents against random Chinese companies.

Don't believe me? Lets look at what happened when Google Waymo, one of the largest companies in the world, tried to sue Uber for LIDAR patent infringement:

[https://www.engadget.com/2018-10-02-waymo-self-driving-lidar-patent-infringement-uber-velodyne.html](https://www.engadget.com/2018-10-02-waymo-self-driving-lidar-patent-infringement-uber-velodyne.html)

&#x200B;

>The US Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO) **rejected 53 out of 56 claims in Waymo's 936 patent**...One of the reasons for the rejection is that some of the core design solutions were **previously patented by another lidar manufacturer, Velodyne**. Coincidentally, Velodyne used to sell its lidars to Waymo before the latter decided to build a product of its own from scratch.  
>  
>Theoretically, **Velodyne could now accuse Waymo of infringing its own 558 patent**, based on the USPTO's recent ruling.
